'''''Boletus fibrillosus''''' is a [[basidiomycota|basidiomycete]] [[fungus]] of the [[genus]] ''[[Boletus]]'' found in western [[North America]]. The [[basidiocarp|fruiting bodies]] are found in mixed coastal forests in the fall.  The [[pileus (mycology)|cap]] is up to 17 cm wide, buff to brown to dark brown in color, and has a wrinkled to finely fibrous texture.  The tubes are yellow, while the flesh is white to buff and does not stain when cut.  The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is yellow at the top, brown otherwise, and has a reticulate texture.  The [[holotype]] was collected in [[Mendocino County, California]].<ref name=thiers75/><ref name=bess00/>

[[Phylogenetics|Phylogenetic]] analysis has shown ''B. fibrillosus'' as a member of a [[clade]], or closely related group, with ''[[Boletus pinophilus|B. pinophilus]]'', ''[[Boletus regineus|B. regineus]]'', ''[[Boletus rex-veris|B. rex-veris]]'', ''[[Boletus subcaerulescens|B. subcaerulescens]]'', and ''[[Gastroboletus subalpinus]]''.<ref name=dent10/>
